case_name: Amrit Lal Berry (Writ Petition No. 463 of 1971) and N. Kapur & 14 others (Writ Petition No. 2004 of 1973)

facts.text: Amrit Lal Berry filed Writ Petition No. 463 of 1971 under Article 32 of the Constitution of India complaining of violation of Article 16.

anchor.surface_text: Amrit Lal Berry in Writ Petition No. 463 of 1971 and N. Kapur 14 others in Writ Petition No. 2004 of 1973 have applied to this Court under Article 32 of the Constitution of India. They companyplain of violation of Article 16 of the Constitution on the ground that they were illegally discriminated against by the respondents inasmuch as they were number companyfirmed and then promoted when they ought to have been.

facts.text: N. Kapur and 14 others filed Writ Petition No. 2004 of 1973 under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: Amrit Lal Berry in Writ Petition No. 463 of 1971 and N. Kapur 14 others in Writ Petition No. 2004 of 1973 have applied to this Court under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Amrit Lal Berry was appointed as Inspector in Central Excise Collectorate at Delhi by orders dated 22-11-1948 and posted at Ferozepur on 4-12-1948.

anchor.surface_text: Amrit Lal Berry was appointed Inspector in the Central Excise Collectorate at Delhi, by orders dated 22-11-1948, and, on 4-12-1948, was posted at Forozepur.

facts.text: Ministry of Home Affairs issued Office Memorandum dated 22-6-1949 determining seniority of existing Govt. servants by date of appointment and from date of confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: On 22-6-1949, the Ministry of Homo  1  1972 2 S.C.R. 992. Affairs. issued a Memorandum companytaining the principle that the, seniority of existing Govt. servants will be determined by the date of their appointment and number from the date of their companyfirmation.

facts.text: Amrit Lal Berry was confirmed in permanent post under order dated 5-5-1956 with effect from 1-7-1955.

anchor.surface_text: after the petitionerhad been companyfirmed in a permanent post under an order dated 5-5-1956 with effect from 1-7-1955.

facts.text: Narinder Singh, appointed on 7-2-1949, was confirmed retrospectively with effect from 1-7-1953.

anchor.surface_text: although, the petitioner is a A. and shown as appointed on 15-12-1948, and Narinder Singh, the Inspector next in order of seniority, who was only a Matriculate, appointed subsequently on 7-2-1949, was companyfirmed retrospectively with effect from 1-7-1953

facts.text: Office Memorandum dated 22-12-1959 altered the rule for seniority in Excise Department to be determined from dates of confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: But, after the Office Memorandum dated 22-12-1959, the rule applied was altered in the Excise Department. New seniority lists were prepared in which seniorities were determined from the dates of companyfirmation.

facts.text: Twelve juniors to Amrit Lal Berry were promoted as Superintendents in 1970-1971 due to impugned seniority list of 1-7-1967.

anchor.surface_text: Government servants, who ought to have been placed below the petitioner have been, it, is asserted, promoted as Superintendents of Central Excise in the years 1970 to 1971. The petitioner gave a list of twelve juniors who have been so promoted because, according to him, the impugned seniority list of 1-7-1967 illegally put them above the petitioner.

facts.text: Amrit Lal Berry given senior inspector grade on 8-12-1967 instead of 21-3-1961.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner also companyplained that, owing to the illegally prepared seniority list, he had been given the grade of a Senior Inspector only on 8-12-1967 and number with effect from 21-3-1961 as it ought to have been done.

facts.text: Amrit Lal Berry's petition filed on 9-12-1971.

anchor.surface_text: Amrit Lal Berrys petition to this Court was filed on 9-12-1971.

facts.text: Amrit Lal Berry sought amendment on 9-3-1973 to quash OM dated 22-7-1972.

anchor.surface_text: By an application dated 9-3-1973, Amrit Lal Berry sought an amendment of his Writ Petition asking this Court to quash the Office Memorandum dated 22-7-1972

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment in Union of India v. M. Ravi Varma on 4-1-1972.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of this Court in Ravi Varmas case  supra  delivered on 4-1-1972.

facts.text: N. Kapur appointed as Inspector on 15-5-1944.

anchor.surface_text: N. Kapur and 14 others also give the dates of their appointments as Inspectors ranging from 15-5-1944 in the case of K. N. Kapur to 19-1-1950 in the case of Ravinderlal.

facts.text: Dates of confirmation for N. Kapur and others vary from 1-7-1956 to 1-12-1962.

anchor.surface_text: The dates of companyfirmation vary from 1-7-1956, in the case of N. Kapur, to 1-12-1962, in the case of S. L. Chopra.

facts.text: Seniority list of 1961 ignored 1949 OM principles.

anchor.surface_text: The whole mischief, according to the petitioners, resulted from misplacing of the names of the petitioners, after the 1959 memorandum, in the seniority list of 1961, which ignored the companyrect or applicable principle for preparation of the senio rity lists according to the memorandum of 1949.

facts.text: Ministry of Home Affairs issued OM dated 22-7-1972 interpreting Ravi Varma judgment.

anchor.surface_text: office Memorandum dated 22-7-1972 was baud on a wrong interpretation of the law laid down by this Court

facts.text: OM 22-6-1949 determined seniority based on length of continuous service in the grade.

anchor.surface_text: under the orders companytained in Ministry of Home Affairs O.M. No. 30/44/48- Apptts., dated 22-6-1949,  companyy enclosed as annexure 1 , seniority in a grade was to be determined, as a general rule, oil the basis of the total length of companytinuous service in the grade

facts.text: OM 22-12-1959 issued revised principles of seniority in consultation with UPSC.

anchor.surface_text: revised principles of seniority were issued in December, 1959, in companysultation- with the Union Public Service Commission, vide Ministry of Home Affairs O.M. No. 91/11/55-RPS, dated 22-12-1959

facts.text: Supreme Court in Ravi Varma case held that 1959 OM principles do not have retrospective effect for pre-1959 appointees.

anchor.surface_text: the companyrt has number agreed with the view taken by the Ministry of Home Affairs  number Department of Personnel  in this matter, as outlined in para 3 above. The companyrt while dismissing the three appeals has held that, except in certain cases  with which the Court were number companycerned , the general principles embodied in the annexure to the O.M. of 22-12-1959 did number have retrospective effect and companyld number apply to persons appointed to the various Central Services before that date.

facts.text: OM 22-7-1972 provides that seniority as on 21-12-1959 be restored with effect from 4-1-1972 without affecting prior confirmations or promotions.

anchor.surface_text: seniority of such persons should, with effect front 4th January 1972  the date of the judgment of the Supreme Court  be restored as it stood on 21-12-1959 in the grade companycerned, irrespective of the fact or date of their companyfirmation and such persons along with those appointed on a regular basis to the grade prior to 22-12- 1959, shall companytinue to remain en bloc senior to the persons appointed to that grade after 22-12-1959. The revision of seniority in such cases will number, however, affect the companyfirmations already made in the grade prior to 4th January, 1972 or regular promotions therefrom prior to that date.

anchor.surface_text: the uncontroverted assertion in paragraph 3 of the companynt affidavit dated 10-10-73 of Shri N. Subramanian, Under Secretary, that the petitioner did number pass the prescribed departmental examination until November 1954.

holdings.text: The Office Memorandum dated 22-7-1972 correctly interprets and applies the judgment in Ravi Varma's case by restoring seniority as it stood on 21-12-1959 with effect from 4-1-1972 without affecting prior confirmations or promotions made before that date.

anchor.surface_text: If the 1972 memorandum correctly interprets and applies the law laid down by this Court there would be no need to proceed further with the consideration of the petitions before us. This memorandum itself gives the history

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Ravi Varma holding that 1959 OM has no retrospective effect; balances by protecting accrued rights from prior confirmations and promotions while applying 1949 principles prospectively from judgment date.

holdings.text: The petitioners have not established violation of Article 16(1) as there is no showing of denial of equality of opportunity to similarly situated persons; differences in confirmation justified by factors like passing departmental exams.

anchor.surface_text: fundamental rights under Article 16 1  of the Constitution... In order to succeed... the petitioner has to disclose how his fundamental right has been infringed... The equality of opportunity...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 16 requires disclosure of infringement and equal treatment for similars; petitioner's delay in exam passing justifies later confirmation; no unjust discrimination shown.

holdings.text: The petitions are barred by principles of laches and acquiescence due to inordinate unexplained delay, allowing equitable rights to accrue to third parties via long-standing confirmations and promotions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Equitable doctrine, not rigid law; delay creates third-party rights; follows Rabindra Nath Bose; distinguished from cases without third-party rights.

holdings.text: No need to decide whether petitions suffer from misjoinder of causes of action or petitioners as they are dismissed on other grounds.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary given dismissal on laches and merits.

holdings.text: Petition of K.N. Kapur and others lacks prior demand for justice and refusal, a condition precedent for writ of mandamus.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Kamini Kumar rule; no assertion of demand/refusal in petition.

holdings.text: Fixation of 4-1-1972 as cut-off date in 1972 OM is not arbitrary as it is the date of the Ravi Varma judgment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Date logically tied to Supreme Court judgment clarifying law; provides prospective effect post-declaration.

holdings.text: Principles in 1949 OM determine seniority by total length of continuous service in the grade as general rule.

anchor.surface_text: under the orders contained in Ministry of Home Affairs O.M. No. 30/44/48- Apptts., dated 22-6-1949... seniority in a grade was to be determined, as a general rule, on the basis of the total length of continuous service in the grade

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct from OM text; applied to pre-1959 appointees per Ravi Varma.

holdings.text: 1959 OM principles are prospective and do not apply retrospectively to pre-1959 appointees.

anchor.surface_text: the court has not agreed... the general principles embodied in the annexure to the O.M. of 22-12-1959 did not have retrospective effect and could not apply to persons appointed to the various Central Services before that date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Ravi Varma and earlier Mervyn Coutinho; explicit in 1959 OM para 2.

anchor.surface_text: Marvyn Coutindo Ors. v. Collector of Customs, Bombay Ors., 1  held that the new principle of seniority, companytained in memorandum of 22-12-1959, was number to apply retrospectively. In fact, the so called new principle of 1959 was a restoration of a principle applied before the memorandum of 1949 issued to meet a special and unprecedented situation created by the

precedents.case_name: Mervyn Coutinho v. Collector of Customs
precedents.cited_proposition: new principle of seniority contained in memorandum of 22-12-1959 was not to apply retrospectively

precedents.citation: Rabindra Nath Bose Ors. v. Union of India Ors. 1 1970 2 S.C.R. 697.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the opposite parties has relied on Rabindra Nath Bose Ors. v. Union of India Ors.  1  where, because rights of persons who had benefited from allegedly illegal seniority rules for a long time would be disturbed, this Court dismissed a petition under Article 32 on the ground of inordinate delay in seeking relief.

precedents.case_name: Rabindra Nath Bose v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 32 petition dismissed due to inordinate delay where rights had accrued to respondents
precedents.cited_holding: it would be unjust to deprive the respondents of the rights which have accrued to them

precedents.citation: Ramchandra Shankar Deodhar Ors. v. the State of Maharashtra Ors., 2 1974 1 S.C.C, 317 325-26

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the petitioners has relied upon observations in a recent decision of this Court in Ramchandra Shankar Deodhar Ors. v. the State of Maharashtra Ors.,  2  where after companysidering earlier cases It was observed  at p. 325-326  There was a delay of more than ten or twelve years

precedents.case_name: Ramchandra Shankar Deodhar v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: delay not a bar to Art 32 relief if no third party rights have arisen
precedents.cited_holding: the rule that the Court may not inquire into belated claims is a rule of practice, not law; each case depends on facts

precedents.citation: Tilokchand Motichand v. H. B. Munshi t 1969 2 S.C. R.824.

anchor.surface_text: The following principle laid down in Tilokchand Motichand v. H. B. Munshi t  was also affirmed The party claiming fundamental rights must move the Court before other rights come into existence.

precedents.case_name: Tilokchand Motichand v. H. B. Munshi
precedents.cited_proposition: party claiming fundamental rights must move the Court before other rights come into existence

precedents.citation: Union of India v. Vasant Jayaram Karnik Ors. 1 A.I.R. 1970 S.C. 2092.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the petitioner relied upon Union of India v. Vasant Jayaram Karnik Ors.  1  to companytend that violation of a rule relating to seniority in cadre or grade would be enough to base a claim for relief on the footing that he is denied equality of opportunity.

precedents.case_name: Union of India v. Vasant Jayaram Karnik

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the rule recognised by this Court is Kamini Kumar Das Choudhury v. State of West Bengal Ors.  1 , that a demand for justice and its refusal must precede the filing of a petition asking for direction or Writ of Mandamus, would also operate against the petitioners.

precedents.cited_proposition: demand for justice and its refusal is condition precedent for mandamus

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed upon D. R. Nim v. Union of India, 8  where a date fixed for the application of a particular rule was held to be arbitrary.

precedents.case_name: D. R. Nim v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: fixation of arbitrary date for application of rule invalid
